QualityOfLife(*args, **kwargs) WORK IN PROGRESS - Class definition prone to rapid change
Recipient(*args, **kwargs) Extension of an OrganPerson record (via OneToOne link for good ORM/DB management) to capture the Recipient specific data.
VersionControlModel(*args, **kwargs) Internal common attributes to aide system auditing of records
class wp4.health_economics.models.QualityOfLife(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

WORK IN PROGRESS - Class definition prone to rapid change

Collects Quality of Life results for a given recipient on a specific date

Parameters:
  • id (django.db.models.AutoField) – “ID”
  • version (django.db.models.PositiveIntegerField) – “version” - Internal tracking version number
  • created_on (django.db.models.DateTimeField) – “created on”
  • created_by_id (django.db.models.ForeignKey) – “created by” - User account for the person logged in when this record was made/updated
  • record_locked (django.db.models.BooleanField) – “record locked” - Not presently implemented or used
  • recipient_id (django.db.models.ForeignKey) – “recipient” - Internal link to the Recipient
  • date_recorded (django.db.models.DateField) – “QL07 date recorded” - Date can not be in the future
  • qol_mobility (django.db.models.PositiveSmallIntegerField) – “QL01 qol mobility score” - Answer must be in range 1-5
  • qol_selfcare (django.db.models.PositiveSmallIntegerField) – “QL02 qol self care score” - Answer must be in range 1-5
  • qol_usual_activities (django.db.models.PositiveSmallIntegerField) – “QL03 qol usual activites score” - Answer must be in range 1-5
  • qol_pain (django.db.models.PositiveSmallIntegerField) – “QL04 qol pain or discomfort score” - Answer must be in range 1-5
  • qol_anxiety (django.db.models.PositiveSmallIntegerField) – “QL05 qol anxiety or depression score” - Answer must be in range 1-5
  • vas_score (django.db.models.PositiveSmallIntegerField) – “QL06 vas score” - Answer must be in range 0-100
recipient¶

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many-to-one or one-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

exception DoesNotExist¶
exception QualityOfLife.MultipleObjectsReturned¶
QualityOfLife.created_by¶

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many-to-one or one-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

QualityOfLife.followup1y_set¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

QualityOfLife.followup3m_set¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.
